Ron Paul is a texas republican, and does not support any of those 3 statements.
 
 States should not be forced at a federal level to recognize gay marriage from other states, but if they choose to recognize such marriages, they should be allowed to do so.
 Opposes Constitutional Amendment banning same-sex marriage.
 Homosexuality is compatible with military service - sexual activity, either gay or straight, which is disruptive to the proper functioning of the organisation, should be dealt with, but gays should by no means be specifically targetted, and certainly not excluded merely for the fact that they are openly gay.
 
 So I agree with Kronus that you should be more specific about who you attribute these beliefs and policies too. Certainly the democrats on the whole are more likely to reject such claims, though some of them too would agree with them, but there are some republicans, even texas republicans running for president, that reject such ideas.

 The thing to remember is that gay rights are a fairly young cause, or at least that they've only very recently started to get good traction. As much as I would like it, I don't really expect everyone to pick up the banner immediately, especially not those who are by nature conservative. I do believe, however, that the more moderate republicans will swing over in due course, as long as they aren't alienated before hand. Call someone your enemy and they will become your enemy, and gay rights have enough real enemies without inventing more. Allow for the possibility of finding common ground and it might just happen, and instead of an enemy you have an ally. But if the "official" gay rights line is that all republicans are by definition evil then we've lost half the country right there, and gay rights are doomed.
